docs.lead_paragraph: At our latest from Texas all was quiet throughout the length and breadth of its extensive frontier, and the measures adopted by Gen. SMITH to insure tranquility can hardly fail of success. Small maransing bands of Camanches may slip through the chain of posts at times, but their depredations must be of minor consequence, and ample punishment will almost certainly follow the commission of any overtact on the part of the savages.

headline.main: HISTORICAL SOCIETY LECTURES.; The Culture, the Support and the Objects of Art in a Republic. A LECTURE--BY GEORGE BANCROFT, LL. D.

docs.lead_paragraph: The first of the series of Lectures before the New-York Historical Society, for the benefit of the Fire-Proof Building Fund, was delivered last evening at Metropolitan Hall by Hon. GEORGE BANCROFT. The audience was large and comprised the most intelligent and respectable of our citizens.
docs.abstract: Mr Bancroft on art in a Republic

headline.main: ANNUAL REPORT OF THE SECRETARY OF WAR.

docs.lead_paragraph: WAR DEPARTMENT, WASHINGTON, Dec. 4, 1852. SIR: I beg leave to submit a brief account of the operations of this Department during the year. The efforts of the Department have been principally directed to the defence of our frontiers and those of Mexico from the Indian tribes within our borders.

headline.main: ANNUAL REPORT OF THE SECRETARY OF THE NAVY.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress held a short session yesterday. The debate in the Senate on the Kentucky contested seat was postponed until Monday next. Mr. CLEMENS introduced his promised resolution to confer the rank of Brevet Lieutenant-General upon General SCOTT. Mr. GWIN gave notice of a bill granting Public Lands for the construction of a Railroad from the Father of Waters to the Pacific--the particular starting-point not named.
docs.abstract: Gives notice of bill to create Gen. Scott Lieut. General

In Brooklyn. on Monday, the 5th inst., of consumption, WILLIAM M. ROYCE. aged 45 years.

docs.lead_paragraph: LATER FROM SANTA FE.--The Santa Fe mail reached Independence on the 27th ult. It was delayed somewhat below its usual time. This delay has been in consequence of frequent storms of rain, sleet and snow. At Fort Union, the snow had fallen to the depth of eighteen or twenty inches. On the Journada, but little was to be seen Nearer the States, the ground was covered, more or less, according to locality.

docs.lead_paragraph: SIXTH ANNUAL DINNER OF THE ST. NICHOLAS SOCIETY OF NASSAU ISLAND.--On Monday evening, the members of this Society, and invited guests from all parts of Long Island assembled at the Hotel of JOHN I. SNEDIKER'S, on the Brooklyn and Jamaica Plank-road to partake of their Annual dinner, and on this occasion also to elect a President in place of General JEREMIAH JOHNSON, deceased.

headline.main: The Shipwrights' and Caulkers' Organization of a Benevolent Society.

docs.lead_paragraph: The first organized meeting ot the Shipwrights and Caulkers of the City and County of New-York was held Monday evening at Chatham Hall, Chathana-square. There are upwards of 1,000 men in the City who are employed in this trade, and although the movers in this benevolent object have only held three preliminary meet ings prior to the one last night, they have already about 275 members.
